key_points: Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson vows to stop using real guns on sets of Seven Bucks Productions film projects after the 'Rust' movie set shooting.
The fatal 'Rust' shooting incident killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and injured director Joel Souza.
The incident has sparked calls to ban real firearms on film sets.
Johnson expressed heartbreak over the incident and extended his sympathies to the victims' families.
Announced that 'Red Notice' will be the last project for Seven Bucks Productions to use real guns.
Johnson's company, Seven Bucks Productions, co-founded with Dany Garcia, will switch to rubber guns and handle effects in post-production.
Emphasized the importance of safety on sets and the need to reassess protocols after the incident.
Armorer Hannah Gutierrez Reed contested how live ammunition was present on set, insisting on safety measures she had undertaken.
Gutierrez Reed's lawyers argued against her culpability, citing potential negligence from the producers regarding safety.
Investigators found a mix of live rounds, blanks, and dummies among 500 rounds of ammunition on the 'Rust' set, raising concerns about safety compliance.
